file_content.text: Mm-hm.
Right.
We have a most excellent partnership, my lord.
The galaxy is stranger and far more dangerous than I'd ever dreamed. It's wonderful!
I just wanted to thank you again for having me along.
I'm honored to work with someone of your expertise. The archaeological pursuits of the Sith and Empire have been separate for too long.
It is our common history. We have a shared duty to unearth it.
This is strictly a business relationship. I want items of power, and you have the knowledge to find them for me.
Don't get too attached.
The path to items of power is paved with pottery shards and broken carvings. But I'll try to spare you the boring bits.
I didn't bring you along as part of some archaeological manifesto.
That's not why you're here.
I'm sorry, my lord. I have a tendency to get carried away.
Sith rarely seek knowledge for its own sake. Your purity is refreshing.
I think we'll get along.
I wouldn't consider myself purer than anyone else in my line of work. I am honored to do what I do.
From the depths of the ground, history calls us to save it from obscurity. I do my best to answer that call.
I can tell you do the same. You remind me of my old mentor, Auselio Gann.
I'll take that as a compliment.
Thank you.
I meant it as a compliment. He was the best there ever was.
So you're saying I look like an old man?
That's hardly flattering.
Uh, no, my lord, I didn't mean--the resemblance is in spirit. I was referring to your love of knowledge.
He was the one who discovered... something about Naga Sadow's secret apprentice?
You mentioned him before.
Advanced archaeology a hundred years--no detail ever escaped him.
But what am I doing talking when there's work to be done. As we say in the service, the dead aren't getting any younger.
My lord, I just wanted to thank you, again. The wonders I have seen working by your side are more than I could have ever hoped.
Truly, you are a paragon among Sith and the Empire.
Thank you for your kind words.
How nice of you to say.
Are you angling for something here?
What do you want?
Only the honor of continuing to serve you.
I seek only knowledge. If it serves the Empire, then good.
I'm just following my passion.
That's precisely what I admire about you, my lord. Your love of knowledge.
It's gone out of practice, but there's evidence that certain non-Force users used to pledge themselves as loyal vassals to true Sith.
These vassals and their families were bound to the Sith and their family for generations. Will you accept my pledge to you and your heirs?
I would be remiss to turn down such a heartfelt offer.
I accept.
I couldn't possibly ask that of you.
You're too kind.
Your humility is one of your most admirable traits, but this is not the place for it.
It's an honor to serve you.
I won't reject an offer of servitude, no matter how pathetic.
I can see profit in this.
Yes, I suppose to you it must seem pathetic. To me, it is a great honor. Thank you.
My lord. I return, but Auselio Gann does not. He's dead.
Doing his work.
My mentor was not weak.
He was pursued by both Jedi and Sith. He managed to use the tomb's traps against them. But in the process, he imprisoned himself.
His discoveries are amazing. They will make a wonderful paper. But I can't help but wonder if it was worth dying for.
What do you mean by that?
I don't understand.
Well, I don't know. I suppose you're right. It's silly of me to doubt.
Were there any artifacts of power in this tomb? If not, then no.
That depends on my gains...
I suppose you're right. What's the point of going after old, dead things if they don't give you some advantage in the present?
No, what am I saying? Auselio Gann would die if he were alive to hear that!
You've given your life to reclaiming the Empire's past. Are you telling me it's not worth dying for?
Don't give up on me.
You know, you're right! How silly it was of me to doubt.
And to think, I was considering tendering my resignation. Oh what would Auselio Gann think if he could see me now?
I must continue his work. Thank you for restoring my faith, my lord.
You know, I'm not sure I'd go that far....
You give me too much credit.
No, my lord. No need to be modest.
The historical mind is ever curious and never sated!
My lord! My lord! I've solved it. The chain in the medallion contained a holofrequency. I wanted you here when I called it.
Don't waste any time, call.
Go on.
Why would your mentor hide a holofrequency in the chain? Why wouldn't he just tell you?
Very odd.
I'm confident Auselio Gann had his reasons.
This isn't my problem.
Not interested.
It seems too good to be true. I must rely on your judgment that it's not a trick.
Talos, my student. If you are receiving this message, then you have understood the riddle I gave you.
I've gone to the tomb of Vaius Antinus's unnamed apprentice, on Aduba Six. I don't understand why, but both Sith and Jedi are after this tomb and its secrets.
It's the duty of the Imperial Reclamation Service to preserve this history. If I do not return, come find me, and finish my work.
Auselio Gann is in trouble. He needs me. I must find him!
You really care about him, don't you?
Such loyalty.
I suppose he was like a father to me. Not my father, but other people's fathers. Or an uncle. An older, smiling uncle. Who brings treats.
This was an automated message. Who knows what has happened in the meantime?
Assuming he's still alive.
I know what could have happened. That won't stop me from going to Aduba-6.
Find your mentor. Help him. Good luck.
Go.
I can think of no more fitting place to die than a tomb, but I will do my best to return safely.
Cruel nemesis, torment me no further! I surrender! I'm not worthy of finding Auselio Gann. He was depending on me, and I failed.
Don't give up so easily. We can crack this.
Let me help.
My lord, I would welcome your expertise.
You're an officer in the Imperial military. Pull yourself together.
You're a mess.
Yes, my lord. I apologize.
Are you telling me that the best archaeologist in the galaxy can't figure this out?
How pathetic.
The best archaeologist? Well, I'm flattered, my lord, but I'm hardly--I mean, I wouldn't say that.
I've tried everything. I've even gone back to the medallion to see if my mentor left me any other clue.
If the Imperial Reclamation Service knew how many codes I violated trying to decipher this medallion, they'd have me stripped of my rank.
Is it possible the solution is not on the medallion itself? Did your mentor give you anything else?
Try a new approach.
The only thing that came with the medallion was the chain, but it clearly wasn't part of the original.
That's it! The chain was new when Auselio Gann gave it to me. That means he's the one who attached it in the first place! Thank you, my lord.
Don't worry. I won't report you.
Your secret's safe with me.
Thank you, my lord. I suppose I will just have to let it rest. Perhaps when my mind is fresh, I can evaluate the situation from a new angle.
Wait! Why didn't I see this before. The medallion came with a chain. It wasn't the original, so I thought it wasn't important. How wrong I was.
Best of luck finding your mentor.
You're welcome.
Thank you, my lord.
How could you overlook something so obvious?
How pathetic.
I know. I'm ashamed. I would resign the service entirely if it wasn't imperative I find my mentor.
I often find when something's difficult it helps to approach it from another direction.
Keep an open mind.
Once again, my limitations are exposed.
If you'll excuse me, I must examine the chain more closely. I'm confident it's the key to finding him.
Don't trouble me with this until you have a solution.
I don't care.
Yes, my lord. I'm sorry. I'll let you know when I know something.
My lord. I think we make an excellent team. Truly, destiny herself has conspired to bring us together!
Your help has been extremely valuable.
You're welcome.
I'm sorry, Talos, I like you, but I just don't think of you that way.
Are you flirting with me?
No! No, that's not, I mean, I didn't mean it that way, of course.
Great. So I'll never be rid of you.
I'm stuck with you then.
Um, yes, never mind then. I thought... I'm sorry.
I was just joking with you. You're an important member of this team, and I value your support.
That was sarcasm.
Thank you, my lord.
I've learned so much at your side; my archaeologist's instincts are honed to a razor's edge. Or a pick's point, as the case may be.
Watch your familiarity in the future.
Don't let it happen again.
Of course, my lord.
I was just trying to express my gratitude. I'm a better archaeologist than I've ever been, thanks to your expertise.
Just leave me alone.
Go away.
Yes, my lord.
Did you have any luck finding your mentor?
No, my lord. I'm afraid the trip was all for nothing. Auselio Gann was already gone, and nobody could tell me where.
He was definitely in the tomb of Vaius Antinus--his workmanship was all over the site. But he left no clue that I could find.
Next time you won't be in such a hurry to run off on a foolish errand.
So it was a waste of time.
Hm. Perhaps it was foolish to go chasing after such a tiny clue. Still, I won't stop looking.
I'm sorry you couldn't find him.
That's a shame.
I'm sure he'll turn up somewhere.
Don't give up hope.
Don't you worry. I've not given up hope.
Detective work such as this isn't much different from archaeology, after all. It's all about observation and deduction, and Auselio Gann taught me well.
Oh! I almost forgot--I found this in the tomb of Vaius Antinus. I thought you might find it handy.
Um, I'm not sure what this is supposed to be.
Great. What is it?
I do love presents.
Hooray!
I don't need your trifles.
I don't want it.
A trifle! My lord, I think you misunderstand.
Vaius Antinus was a meticulous record-keeper. These are the geneologies of all the great Sith Lords of his day. Look--here is your ancestor, Lord Kallig.
Bloodlines are very important in the Empire, my lord. Not to mention the historical value!
My lord! I've solved it! I've figured it out!
I don't understand how I could've missed it. The outer layer of the medallion responds to heat! It melted away and revealed this!
It's a heat-resistant casing, with a data chip inside!
Applying heat to an object like that--you could've destroyed it!
What a dumb thing to do.
Unofficial motto of the Imperial Reclamation Service: When all else fails, try a blowtorch.
Actually, that would be disastrous. I did a chemical sampling first.
I suspected the medallion was not uniform all the way through. I was right.
Why would your mentor bother sending you secret messages?
I don't understand.
I'm sure there's a perfectly logical, not-remotely-scary explanation. I just haven't thought of it yet.
What did you discover?
Any new information?
It certainly took you long enough.
You're slow.
We archaeologists can be a bit narrow-minded sometimes. I assumed that because the medallion was a fake, it wasn't important.
I'm beginning to believe your claims that your mentor was a genius.
Fascinating.
He was certainly one of a kind.
The chip said he was looking for the tomb of Vaius Antinus. He said he was going to Malachor Three, but everyone knows the tomb is on Alderaan!
Remind me again why I care.
Why are you telling me this?
Since you'd shown an interest so far, my lord, I thought you'd like to know how my search was going.
I believe Auselio Gann went to Alderaan. I'm going to find him.
My lord, remember I told you about my mentor, Auselio Gann? He took me under his wing after I discovered the domesticated rancor tooth.
I was polishing the rancor tooth and placing it among my things, when I noticed a medallion he gave me last time we met.
I decided to call him, but none of his frequencies work anymore.
When was the last time you spoke to him?
Did you see him recently?
He might just be on a dig somewhere remote.
I'm sure it's nothing.
Never go to a dig site on your own, and never go without making sure someone knows. Second rule of archaeology.
I spoke to him only a little while ago. We met at a cantina on Nar Shaddaa for a little light archaeological talk.
One old archaeologist is nothing to me.
What makes you think I care?
My lord, with all respect, how can you say that? Doctor Gann is the Empire's premiere Naga Sadow scholar!
You wouldn't have found the ghost on Hoth without me, and I wouldn't have been able to help you if it hadn't been for Auselio Gann.
By that logic, I should thank your mother and father for your birth as well.
That makes no sense.
You fulfilled your duty as an Imperial soldier. You receive your payment from the Empire.
I don't owe you anything.
Fine, my lord. But with your permission, I'm going to start looking for him myself.
You do as you wish on your own time.
It doesn't matter to me.
Thank you, my lord.
You do not have my permission.
No, you may not.
Understood, my lord.
Just don't neglect your service to me.
My work comes first.
Of course not. I meant no disloyalty to you.
When was the last time you spoke to him?
Fine. Tell me about it.
It was before I went to Hoth. We met at a cantina on Nar Shaddaa for a little light archaeological talk.
He said he was on his way to Malachor Three. That's when he gave me the medallion. It's the last I saw of him.
What was this medallion he gave you?
Medallion?
Oh, it was just a knockoff. He said some Hutt tried to pass it off as the real thing. It was quite canny, though.
Did he act strange at the time?
How was he then?
Not really. Maybe a little at the end.
Malachor Three is pretty remote. He probably just fell out of touch.
It's a big galaxy.
You're probably right.
I can't help but think of something odd he said just before we left. He gave me the medallion and said something like "in case you need me."
I just thought he'd had too much to drink. He did love to imbibe.
If you need my help searching for him, you'll have it.
Let me know how I can help.
Well, thank you.
Does the medallion have anything written on it?
Perhaps it's a clue.
No, just old runes. Most of it nonsense.
Maybe he got drunk and fell in a tomb.
He doesn't sound too bright.
No! Auselio Gann never drank on the job. Well, maybe a little. But only enough to keep warm.
I'm sure it's nothing. You can't keep an Imperial Reclamation Service man down.
I guess I'll keep an ear and an eye out. I'll let you know if I discover anything.
You'll never believe what I found! I thought I'd left this behind planets ago!
Is it some kind of artifact?
What is it?
The anticipation is killing me.
Something dull, I suspect.
This is the tooth off a four-thousand-year-old proto-rancor. But look, see this? It's some kind of metal, not cortosis, but very similar.
This rancor was tamed! It was my very first discovery. I carry it with me everywhere, for luck.
Much as I admire your enthusiasm, Lieutenant Drellik, do not forget I am your superior.
Sounds worthless to me.
Of course, my lord. I apologize. My excitement sometimes gets the better of me.
It's just this was my first discovery--the tooth of a tamed rancor--and I've carried it around with me for ages.
I thought I'd lost it when I fell into an old tomb a couple digs ago. It turns out it was caught in the lining of my pocket!
On Korriban, I pulled an artifact from an ancient holocron that was supposed to be unopenable.
I remember my first discovery.
You mean from the pyramid in the tomb of Marka Ragnos? How did you do it? With a sonic excavator? Or some device of your own?
A Sith must have some secrets.
I don't tell.
I suppose I will have to live with disappointment.
Now, if you'll excuse me, I have some findings to analyze.
I killed thirty tuk'ata and covered myself in their blood.
[Lie] It was quite messy.
Remarkable. How did you come by the number thirty exactly? Was there a clue on the device, or did you simply experiment?
Sith methods are an endless source of fascination to me.
Actually, I just used lightning. It was a disappointingly obvious solution.
I lied about the blood.
I killed tuk'ata until it opened. Simple.
I used trial and error.
The experimental approach, then. Interesting.
Speaking of which, I have some new findings to analyze, if you'll excuse me.
I took one of the faces of the pyramid and created a circle by connecting each of the triangle's corners....
It was rather elaborate.
Fascinating....
What a dizzying process. No wonder it took so long to discover. I am in awe of you, my lord.
It was painfully obvious, really. I used lightning.
I just zapped it.
Hmm. You know, there's a theory in the archaeological world that certain ancient devices, holocrons especially, have resonances.
It's something to do with the Force. Just as only Sith can activate holocrons, some ancient devices can only be activated by certain Sith bloodlines.
Most archaeologists reject it as unscientific. But there's so much about the galaxy we don't understand...who am I to say what's scientific?
Have you worked with many Sith in the past?
Do you know a lot of Sith?
Never closely. Usually in a for-hire arrangement.
The Imperial Reclamation Service may be part of the army, but we get much less funding than our more martial comrades in arms.
People with no knowledge of the Force should not speculate on its workings.
You are nobody.
I'm sorry, my lord. I was not attempting to explain the unexplainable. We in the broader archaeological community have great respect for the Sith.
Such theories are only offered to better understand the nature of the items we research, and to improve our techniques.
I'm not one to dismiss an idea just because it seems a little crazy.
It's a fascinating theory.
Yes, my lord, I thought so.
But if you'll excuse me, I have some new findings to analyze.
You built that up way too much.
What a dumb story.
Are you kidding? This thing has more secrets than half the Sith artifacts you own.
It made my career. Renowned Naga Sadow scholar Auselio Gann caught wind of it and had me assigned to his team.
So how did you go from discovering evidence of domesticated rancors to digging up Sith Lords?
But you're a Sith scholar.
I know. Night and day, aren't they? That was Auselio Gann's doing. He was sort of my mentor.
I've been digging up Sith artifacts ever since. Speaking of which, I have some new findings to analyze. If you'll excuse me.
If you don't mind my asking, how is it you became Sith, my lord? The process is completely foreign to me.
I had a brother who was Force sensitive. Darth Marr came and took him to Korriban, but we didn't hear from him again after that.
"Ungrateful little rat thinks he's too good for us now," my father said. But really, I think he just missed him.
Most of the people who go to Korriban to become Sith die in training.
Your brother's probably dead.
You don't know my brother. He never took no for an answer. We Drellik boys might not look like much, but we fight back!
Many Sith get an extreme sense of superiority and stop talking to their families.
Your father was right.
If I ever run into your brother, I'll let you know.
I'm sorry.
It's alright. We didn't really get along anyway. He was always faster. And stronger. And he usually had a stick in his hand.
Father always wanted one son in the Sith and one in the military.
Admittedly, the Imperial Reclamation Service wasn't his first choice, but after all the cursing stopped, I think he warmed up to the idea.
What did your father have against the Imperial Reclamation Service?
Why was he so angry?
When people think of military heroism, they don't generally think of digging in ancient tombs.
I can't blame him.
No, but we serve a vital purpose.
Your father is a bit of a jerk, isn't he?
Sounds like a loser.
The Drelliks are a proud family line, and my father is simply the proudest of the lot.
The Imperial Reclamation Service shores up the Empire's foundations against the flood of forgetfulness and misinformation that threatens our history.
I'd like to see a fighter pilot establish the lineage of a three-thousand-year-old Sith Lord with nothing but rocks and a dead language.
I have always believed that knowledge will ultimately win out over the lightsaber and the blaster.
It's a noble profession.
Thank you, my lord. It is my honor to serve.
You and the fighter pilot must bow to the Sith.
Both roles are weak.
But who can compare to a Sith, my lord? No one in the Republic or the Empire.
It sounds as if you were too frightened to pick up a blaster and fight for your Empire.
I smell cowardice.
Destiny calls each to his own duty. Who am I to argue with destiny?
So explain this to me. The tomb of Naga Sadow on Korriban was built by Tulak Hord before Naga Sadow was even born?
And that's where you found the Dashade shadow-killer?
And when your master tried to steal your body, you used the artifacts of Tulak Hord to put her being into this Dashade?
Somehow when you describe it, it sounds completely nuts.
It made more sense back then.
It's our job to piece together the puzzle of history.
You forgot the part where I received aid from my long-dead ancestor who was murdered by Tulak Hord.
Don't forget Kallig.
Kallig! He was one of the most powerful Sith Lords of his time. Perhaps the most powerful. And an alien too.
Kallig! He was one of the most powerful Sith Lords of his time. Perhaps the most powerful. Oddly pro-alien.
To think how the Empire might have been different if he had killed Tulak Hord and not the other way around.
Where did you hear all this?
How did you know?
Darth Zash and I have been talking. Well, when she's around. I would love to speak more with Khem Val, but I don't think he likes me.
He only eats Force users.
Don't worry about him.
Yes, I'd read much about his species but never seen one in person. Still, when he gets that hungry glint in his eye....
Being locked in stasis for hundreds of years was hard on him.
I'm sure he'll come around.
Heh. You know, I never thought of it that way. Yes, I'm sure that's it. Perhaps I could give him a few social pointers.
I'm sure he'd appreciate that.
You should.
Excellent. I will speak with him at the next opportunity.
I would leave him alone, if I were you. He's liable to become violent.
I wouldn't advise it.
Nonsense. The monsters I've encountered in the dark corners of tombs make Khem Val look positively civilized.
You're hardly the model of social grace yourself.
You'd be a terrible teacher.
Well, at least I'm polite.
Khem Val respects strength. You're a little on the weak side.
I can see why.
Well, I'd say that's a matter of debate. They don't give lieutenant stripes to just everyone you know.
But your adventures sound fascinating. Five artifacts of Tulak Hord!
I understand you inherited quite the archive from Zash. I would love to see it some time.
I would love to show it to you.
Certainly.
Excellent. The quest for knowledge is eternal!
The knowledge of the Sith is not meant for weaklings like you.
You presume too much.
My apologies. The quest for knowledge is neverending, but perhaps I overstepped.
Some knowledge isn't meant to be seen, you understand.
We'll see.
Nonsense. For people like us, the quest for knowledge is neverending.
If I could have a moment of your time the next time we're on the ship, that would be wonderful.
When you have a moment, can we talk?
I really do enjoy our conversations, but I'm a little too busy to talk right now.
I'm so sorry.
What happened?
The he got what he deserved.
My pleasure.
It's what friends are for.
Yes, my lord. Ready when you are.
Of course, my lord.
Thank you, my lord.
The historical mind is ever curious and never sated!
It's an honor to serve you.
Yes, my lord! With pleasure!
This shouldn't take too long.
I promise, I won't let you down.
If there's any way I can aid you, my lord, let me know.
